column1: 19213`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/may_2017/20170501_Birkhoff_84th_83rd_21w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1701130    May 1
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By mid May 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 1
column7: 042 feet of new 8-inch and 628 feet of new 12-inch  water main in S. Birkhoff Avenue
column8: from W. 83rd Street to S. Vincennes Avenue
column10: from  S. Birkhoff Avenue to S. Vincennes Avenue and W. 83rd Street
column11: from S. Halsted Street to S. Kerfoot  Avenue.  The old water main dates back to 1890
column12: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column13: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column14: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column15: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column16: to the installation of new  pipes
column17: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column18: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column19: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column20: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column21: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column22: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column23: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column24: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  21st Ward Office: 773-881-9300  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column25: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column26: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column27: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column28: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column30: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column32: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column33: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column34: or if you would like your water  tested
column35: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column36: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column37: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column38: if you don’t already have one
column39: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column40: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely

column3: City Clerk   NOTICE OF JOB OPPORTUNITY      Business Administration and Finance -   VOLUNTEER INTERN – UNPAID      TC 0407       DESCRIPTION: The Office of the City Clerk seeks an intern who will assist with  compiling and designing project proposal materials and compiling data in a wide  breadth  of  research  areas.  Additional  responsibilities  may  also  include  economic  research  and  analysis
column6: writing  and  editing  reports  and  presentations  and  graphic  design  depending on the Intern’s interests and talents in this area. The Office of the City  Clerk seeks a candidate with a focus on finance
column7: an interest in urban issues and  with  strong  writing
column8: research  and  communication  skills.  Knowledge  of  Microsoft  Office  software
column10: PowerPoint  and  Excel  is  essential.  Ability  to  use  Bloomberg  software  is  also  a  plus.  Interns  must  be  very  reliable
column13: eager  to  learn  and  highly  organized.  Interns  should  ideally  be  available  to  work  part-time  (at  least  14  to  21  hours  a  week).  Students  will  be  able  to  use  this  opportunity  for  course  credit  if  desired  and  approved.     MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:  Must be a current college (Junior level or  higher) or graduate student in good academic standing
column14: enrolled in an  accredited four year college or university offering a graduate degree  program or an accredited law school. Must have a minimum cumulative  grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 grading scale or a 4.0 on a 5.0  grading scale.  Recent (within one calendar year) graduates of either a  two or four year accredited college or university or graduate degree  program or an accredited law school are also eligible to apply. Must have  had a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 grading  scale or a 4.0 on a 5.0 grading scale.    NOTE: A cumulative GPA of 2.5 on a 4.0 grading scale or a 3.5 on a 5.0  grading scale must be maintained throughout the duration of internship.       PREFERENCE: Students with a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale will be given  preference. Candidates should be able to work in a fast-paced environment.   RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT: Not required   SALARY:  Unpaid – may be used to obtain academic credit.   These are temporary positions.    HOURS:  14 to 21hrs/wk minimum. Hours are flexible to meet the needs of the  student and the department.    CLOSING DATE FOR APPLICATIONS:  Open Until Further Notice    DUTIES: Assigned duties are specific to current operational needs. Perform  various administrative functions to support program activities; compile
column15: tabulate  and analyze statistical data; research and collect information for inclusion in  studies and reports; research and draft policy documents; use various software  packages to type documents
column16: create spreadsheets and maintain databases;  provide general information
column17: maintain records and prepare work activity reports;  perform various office clerical functions; participate in the organization
column18: set-up  and administration of special events and program activities;  and perform related  duties as required.     INSTRUCTION: ALL MATERIALS ARE REQUIRED AT THE TIME OF APPLICATION AND  MUST BE SUBMITTED TOGETHER AS A PACKET.   1.  Cover Letter (noting “Office of the City Clerk
column19: Business Administration and   Finance Intern”)   2. Official/Unofficial Transcript that proves successful graduation   3. Resume   4. Writing Sample    Kathryn O’Connell    Office of the City Clerk   City Hall
column22: IL 60602    OR clerksofficeinternships@cityofchicago.org    NOTE:  Only applicants who submit all the required documents will be  considered.     If you are a person with disability and require a reasonable accommodation in order to  participate in the application process
column23: please contact the City of Chicago
column24: Department of  Human Resources at 312 744-4976 (voice) or 312 744-5035 (TTY). You may be required to  provide information to support your reasonable accommodation request.     ALL REFERENCES TO POLITICAL SPONSORSHIP OR RECOMMENDATION MUST BE OMITTED FROM  ANY AND ALL APPLICATION MATERIALS SUBMITTED FOR CITY EMPLOYMENT    THE CITY OF CHICAGO IS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY/AFFIRMATIVE ACTION EMPLOYER

column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By early March 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 551 feet of new 8-inch water main in E. Balbo  Avenue
column7: from S. State Street to S. Michigan Avenue. The old water main dates back to 1893
column8: and  needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column9: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column10: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column11: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column12: to the installation of new  pipes
column13: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column14: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column15: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column16: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column17: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column18: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column19: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column20: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  4th Ward Office: 773-536-8103  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635        Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main    When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column21: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column22: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column23: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column24: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column26: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column28: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column29: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column30: or if you would like your water  tested
column31: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column32: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column33: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column34: if you don’t already have one
column35: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column36: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.   Sincerely

column1: 17549`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/HealthWelfare/2200_Plumbing_Inspection_Series/2231_PLUMBING_INSPECTOR.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`   Code:  2231  Family: Construction
column3: and Skilled Labor  Service: Health and Welfare   Group: Inspectional  Series: Plumbing Inspection         CLASS TITLE: PLUMBING INSPECTOR  CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS      Under supervision
column4: reviews building plans/plumbing specifications and inspects plumbing systems  to ensure water service pipe installations and connections are in compliance with the plumbing  provisions and sanitation requirements of the municipal building code
column5: and performs related duties  as required      ESSENTIAL DUTIES   •  Reviews plans and construction specifications for plumbing systems submitted with building   permit applications for compliance with applicable sections of the municipal building code  Identifies materials and installation methods that are not in compliance with the municipal  building code
column7: and recommends changes to bring plans into  compliance   •   •  Conducts field inspections to ensure that the installation and repair of plumbing systems adhere   to approved permit plans
column8: construction specifications and plumbing code provisions    •  Ensures that proper materials and sizing of pipe are being used for new water
column10: and vent   plumbing installations and that piping is properly backfilled and supported   •  Observes initial installation and annual testing of approved back flow prevention devices that   prevent used and contaminated water from re-entering potable water supply  Inspects plumbing systems to verify the absence of cross connections between the City's water  supply and secondary
column12: or contaminated water sources   •   •  Prepares reports documenting inspection findings and work reports on inspection activities   Interprets and explains the plumbing provisions of the building code and code violations to  •  contractors and building owners  Issues citations for plumbing code violations found during inspections   •  •  Conducts follow-up inspections to ensure that repairs have been made and that code violations   are corrected   •  Provides inspection results for administrative hearings regarding plumbing violations identified   during inspections and corresponding citations issued   •  Accesses computerized records to review inspection and permit information and maintains and   updates records as required   Inspects job sites for proper permits and ensures plumbing work is performed by licensed and  bonded plumbing contractors   •    NOTE:  The list of essential duties is not intended to be inclusive; there may be other duties that are   essential to particular positions within the class.        MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS   Education
column14: and Experience  •  At least seven (7) years as a licensed Plumber in the State of Illinois      CODE:  2231  CLASS TITLE: PLUMBING INSPECTOR      Licensure
column16: or Other Qualifications  •  A valid plumber's license issued by either the State of Illinois or the City of Chicago is required  •  Must obtain and maintain a license issued by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency as a   Cross-Connection Control Device Inspector within six months of hire    •  A valid State of Illinois driver's license is required  •  Must have the permanent use of an automobile that is properly insured
column17: including a clause   specifically insuring the City of Chicago from accident liability       WORKING CONDITIONS   •  General office environment  •  Exposure to outdoor weather conditions  •  Exposure to fumes or dust
column18: oily or wet environment  •  Exposure to hazardous conditions (e.g.

column26: computer terminals)  •  Cameras and related photography equipment  •  Personal protective equipment (e.g.
column33: two-way radio    PHYSICAL REQUIREMENTS   •  Ability to walk and stand for extended or continuous periods of time  •  Ability to climb staircases
column35: and/or step stools  •  Ability to access multi-level structures and other spaces (e.g.
column43: AND OTHER WORK REQUIREMENTS   Knowledge  Moderate knowledge of:  •  •  •  use of safety equipment and protective gear   •   *plumbing principles
column46: and procedures  *plumbing repair and maintenance procedures   *plumbing safety and code standards (e.g.
column47: plumbing and sanitation requirements for water- waste

column1: 26472`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/SPRINKLER-FITTER_4765.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code:  4765  Operation and Construction Service  Building Maintenance and Operation Group  Steamfitting and Plumbing Trades Series                                  CLASS TITLE:  Sprinkler Fitter    CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under supervision
column2: performs journey  level sprinkler fitting work in the installation
column3: repair and  maintenance of automatic fire sprinkler systems and related piping;  and performs related duties as required.      ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Reads blueprints
column4: specifications and work orders to  assess work required and to determine the proper installation and  repair methods to use; removes damaged
column5: defective or obsolete  sprinkler systems; ensures adequate supplies of tools
column6: equipment and  materials needed to complete jobs are at work sites; uses tools to  measure
column8: bend and fabricate hangers and overhead piping; measures  and marks areas where pipes will be installed and connected; installs  new fire sprinkler systems or extensions to existing systems; inspects  to ensure sprinklers are working properly and are in compliance with  safety and municipal standards; repairs and maintains sprinkler  systems and related equipment; connects piping with adhesive or by  soldering; operates specialized equipment and tools including saws
column9: pipe cutters and pipe bending machines; prepares work activity  reports.        RELATED DUTIES:   Loads
column10: transports and unloads equipment and supplies;  cleans equipment and work site after repairs; cleans and maintains  fire hoses and extinguishers to ensure proper operation.    MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience.  Successful completion of a US Department of  Labor registered sprinkler fitter apprenticeship training program and  journeyman status
column11: or an equivalent combination of training and  experience.    Knowledge
column12: Abilities and Skill.  Good knowledge of the principles
column13: work methods and techniques of the sprinkler fitting trade.  Good  knowledge of safety practices and procedures.  Good knowledge of  municipal building code requirements pertaining to the installation of  fire sprinkler systems.    Ability to read and interpret blueprints and specifications.  Physical  ability to use the tools of the trade.  Ability to access equipment  located above ground level or in confined or cramped areas.  Ability        Code:  4765  Operation and Construction Service  Building Maintenance and Operation Group  Steamfitting and Plumbing Trades Series       CLASS TITLE:  Sprinkler Fitter   (Cont'd)    to prepare work activity reports.     Skill in the installation
column14: repair and maintenance of fire sprinkler  systems.  Skill in the use of tools and equipment of the sprinkler  fitting trade.  Basic math skills.   Basic oral and written  communication skills.      Physical Requirements.  Ability to lift and carry tools and materials  weighing up to 50 pounds frequently and 75 pounds occasionally.      Working Conditions.  Unavoidable exposure to extreme temperatures
column15: fumes and a wet environment.  Work is performed at high levels using  ladders and scaffolds.    Equipment.  Standard tools and equipment of the sprinkler fitting  trade including pipe cutters
column17: wrenches.  Safety equipment.            NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive   as possible
column18: there may be other duties which are essential  to particular positions within the class.            November
